Mastering Issues

ç©è½¬ Issue

Issues are a great way to keep track of tasks, enhancements, and bugs for your projects. Theyâ€™re kind of like emailâ€”except they can be shared and discussed with the rest of your team. Most software projects have a bug tracker of some kind. GitHubâ€™s tracker is called Issues, and has its own section in every repository.

è®®é¢˜ï¼ˆIssueï¼‰æ˜¯ github ä¸­ç®¡ç†ä»»åŠ¡çš„æœ‰æ•ˆæ–¹æ³•ï¼Œå®ƒèƒ½ä¿å­˜ä»»åŠ¡çš„è¿›åº¦ã€è·Ÿè¸ªä»»åŠ¡çš„ç®¡ç†å’Œè¿½æº¯é¡¹ç›®çš„bugsã€‚å®ƒæœ‰ç‚¹åƒå¯ä»¥ç”¨æ¥è·Ÿå›¢é˜Ÿåˆ†äº«å’Œè®¨è®ºçš„é‚®ä»¶ã€‚å¤§å¤šæ•°çš„è½¯ä»¶é¡¹ç›®éƒ½æœ‰å„è‡ª bugs è¿½æº¯ç³»ç»Ÿï¼ŒGitHubçš„è¿½æº¯ç³»ç»Ÿå°±å«åšè®®é¢˜ï¼Œå®ƒåœ¨ github çš„ä»“åº“ä¸­å‘æŒ¥ç€ç‹¬ç‰¹çš„ä½œç”¨ã€‚

For example, letâ€™s take a look at Bootstrapâ€™s Issues section:

ä¸¾ä¸ªä¾‹å­ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬æ¥çœ‹ Bootstrap çš„è®®é¢˜ï¼š

GitHubâ€™s issue tracking is special because of our focus on collaboration, references, and excellent text formatting. A typical issue on GitHub looks a bit like this:

å› ä¸º GitHub çš„è¿ä½œæœºåˆ¶æ›´å…³æ³¨å›¢é˜Ÿçš„åä½œã€å…³è”å’Œé«˜æ•ˆæ²Ÿé€šï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥ issue çš„è¿½æº¯ä¼šè®¾ç½®å¾—æ¯”è¾ƒç‰¹åˆ«ã€‚ä¸€ä¸ªå…¸å‹ GitHub çš„ issue åº”è¯¥æ˜¯è¿™æ ·çš„ï¼š

  • A title and description describe what the issue is all about.
  • Color-coded labels help you categorize and filter your issues (just like labels in email).
  • A milestone acts like a container for issues. This is useful for associating issues with specific features or project phases (e.g. Weekly Sprint 9/5-9/16 or Shipping 1.0).
  • One assignee is responsible for working on the issue at any given time.

  • Comments allow anyone with access to the repository to provide feedback.

  • æœ‰è¯„è®ºï¼ˆcommentï¼‰ï¼Œè¿™æ ·æ‰èƒ½æ¥æ”¶åˆ°åˆ«äººå¯¹ä»“åº“çš„åé¦ˆã€‚

Milestones, Labels, and Assignees

é‡Œç¨‹ç¢‘ã€æ ‡ç­¾å’Œå¯¹æ¥äºº

Once youâ€™ve collected a lot of issues, you may find it hard to find the ones you care about. Milestones, labels, and assignees are great features to filter and categorize issues.

You can change or add a milestone, an assignee, and labels by clicking their corresponding gears in the sidebar on the right.

If you donâ€™t see edit buttons, thatâ€™s because you donâ€™t have permission to edit the issue. You can ask the repository owner to add you as a collaborator to get access.

issue ä¸€æ—¦å¤šäº†èµ·æ¥ï¼Œä½ å°±å¯èƒ½ä¼šä¸€æ—¶æ— å¯é€‚ä»äº†ï¼Œè¿™æ˜¯ä½ å°±éœ€è¦ä½¿ç”¨ issue ä¸­çš„ã€Œé‡Œç¨‹ç¢‘ã€ã€ã€Œæ ‡ç­¾ã€å’Œã€Œå¯¹æ¥äººã€çš„åŠŸèƒ½äº†ï¼Œå®ƒä»¬èƒ½å¤ŸåŠæ—¶å¯¹ issue è¿›è¡Œæ ‡æ³¨å’Œåˆ†ç±»ï¼Œè®©ä½ è¿…é€Ÿåœ°æ‰¾åˆ°ä½ æƒ³è¦çš„ä¿¡æ¯ã€‚

ä½ å¯ä»¥åœ¨å³è¾¹çš„ä¾§æ ä¸­æ‰¾åˆ°ã€Œé‡Œç¨‹ç¢‘ã€ã€ã€Œæ ‡ç­¾ã€å’Œã€Œå¯¹æ¥äººã€çš„å°é½¿è½®ï¼Œå•å‡»å®ƒä»¬çš„å°é½¿è½®ï¼Œä½ å°±å¯ä»¥å¯¹å…¶è¿›è¡Œä¿®æ”¹æˆ–å¢åŠ ã€‚

å¦‚æœä½ æ²¡æœ‰çœ‹åˆ°å¯ç¼–è¾‘çš„å°é½¿è½®ï¼Œé‚£è¯æ˜ä½ è¿˜æ²¡æœ‰å¯ä¿®æ”¹è¯¥ issue çš„æƒé™ï¼Œä½ å¯ä»¥å‘è¯¥ issue çš„ç®¡ç†å‘˜ç”³è¯·ç®¡ç†å‘˜æƒé™ã€‚

Milestones

é‡Œç¨‹ç¢‘

Milestones are groups of issues that correspond to a project, feature, or time period. People use them in many different ways in software development. Some examples of milestones on GitHub include:

  • Beta Launch â€” File bugs that you need to fix before you can launch the beta of your project. Itâ€™s a great way to make sure you arenâ€™t missing anything.

  • October Sprint â€” File issues that youâ€™d like to work on in October. A great way to focus your efforts when thereâ€™s a lot to do.

  • Redesign â€” File issues related to redesigning your project. A great way to collect ideas on what to work on.

ã€Œé‡Œç¨‹ç¢‘ã€æ˜¯ä¸€ç³»åˆ— issue çš„é›†åˆï¼Œå®ƒå¯ä»¥é€šè¿‡é¡¹ç›®ã€åŠŸèƒ½æˆ–æ—¶æ®µæ¥è®¾å®šã€‚ç¨‹åºå‘˜ä»¬å–œæ¬¢ç”¨ã€Œé‡Œç¨‹ç¢‘ã€åœ¨è½¯ä»¶ç®¡ç†ä¸­åšå„ç§å„æ ·çš„äº‹æƒ…ï¼Œä¾‹å¦‚ï¼š

  • Beta æµ‹è¯•ï¼šåœ¨é¡¹ç›® Beta ç‰ˆä¸Šçº¿ä¹‹å‰ï¼Œä½ éœ€è¦å¯¹å„ç§æ–‡ä»¶çš„ bug è¿›è¡Œæ£€æµ‹ï¼Œè®¾å®šã€Œé‡Œç¨‹ç¢‘ã€ç¡®ä¿ä½ ä¸ä¼šé”™è¿‡æ¯ä¸€æ¡ä¿¡æ¯ã€‚
  • åæœˆå†²åˆºï¼šå½“ä½ æœ‰å¾ˆå¤šäº‹æƒ…è¦åšçš„æ—¶å€™ï¼Œä½ å¯ä»¥å°†ä½ è¦åœ¨åæœˆå®Œæˆçš„å·¥ä½œéƒ½é›†ä¸­åœ¨ä¸€èµ·ï¼Œä»¥ä¾¿é›†ä¸­ç²¾åŠ›å¤„ç†ã€‚
  • é‡æ„ï¼šä½ å¯ä»¥åœ¨ã€Œé‡Œç¨‹ç¢‘ã€æ”¶é›†å»ºè®®ï¼Œå°†ç›¸å…³çš„ issue è¿›è¡Œé¡¹ç›®é‡æ„ã€‚

Labels

Labels are a great way to organize different types of issues. Issues can have as many labels as you want, and you can filter by one or many labels at once.

Assignees

Each issue can have an assignee â€” one person thatâ€™s responsible for moving the issue forward. Assignees are selected the same way milestones are, through the grey bar at the top of the issue.

æ ‡ç­¾

ä½ å¯ä»¥ç”¨å„ç§ä½ æƒ³è¦æ ‡ç­¾æ¥æœ‰æ•ˆåœ°ç®¡ç† issueï¼Œæœ‰äº†æ ‡ç­¾ï¼Œä½ ç«‹é©¬å°±å¯ä»¥ä»ä¸€å †æ ‡ç­¾ä¸­ç­›é€‰å‡ºä½ æƒ³è¦çš„ issueã€‚

å¯¹æ¥äºº

æ¯ä¸ª issue éƒ½åº”æœ‰ä¸€ä¸ªè´Ÿè´£æ¨è¿›å¯¹æ¥äººï¼Œå¯¹æ¥äººçš„è®¾å®šæ–¹å¼å’Œé‡Œç¨‹ç¢‘çš„è®¾å®šä¸€æ ·ï¼šç‚¹å‡»å¯¹åº”çš„é½¿è½®æŒ‰é”®é€‰æ‹©å³å¯ã€‚

Notifications, @mentions, and References

By using @mentions and references inside of Issues, you can notify other GitHub users & teams, and cross-connect issues to each other. These provide a flexible way to get the right people involved to resolve issues effectively, and are easy to learn and use. They work across all text fields on GitHub â€” theyâ€™re a part of our text formatting syntax called GitHub Flavored Markdown.

If youâ€™d like to learn more, have a look at Mastering Markdown.

é€šçŸ¥ï¼Œ@æé†’ å’Œ å¼•ç”¨

ä½ å¯ä»¥ä½¿ç”¨ issue ä¸­çš„ @æé†’ å’Œ å¼•ç”¨ æ¥é€šçŸ¥ GitHub ç”¨æˆ·å’Œå›¢é˜Ÿï¼Œæˆ–ç›¸äº’é“¾æ¥åˆ°å…¶ä»–çš„ issueã€‚é€šçŸ¥ï¼Œ@æé†’å’Œå¼•ç”¨ åœ¨ github ä¸­ä½¿ç”¨GitHub Flavored Markdownå…¨æ–‡æœ¬æ ¼å¼çš„æµè½¬ï¼Œä¸Šæ‰‹å®¹æ˜“ï¼Œä¸”èƒ½çµæ´»å‡†ç¡®åœ°é€šçŸ¥å¯¹æ¥äººå¿«é€Ÿé«˜æ•ˆè§£å†³ issue ä¸­çš„é—®é¢˜ã€‚

å¦‚æœä½ æƒ³æ›´å¤šåœ°äº†è§£ GitHub Flavored Markdownï¼Œå¯ç‚¹å‡» Mastering Markdownã€‚

Notifications

Notifications are GitHubâ€™s way to keep up to date with your Issues. You can use them to find out about new issues on repositories, or just to know when someone needs your input to move forward on an issue.

There are two ways to receive notifications: via email, and via the web. You can configure how you receive notifications in your settings. If you plan on receiving a lot of notifications, we like to recommend that you receive web + email notifications for Participating and web notifications for Watching.
